In Prader Willi syndrome, adhere to nutritional guidance and weight management. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. If it is the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. Do not take extra doses. If you miss more than one dose, contact your clinician. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include injection site reactions, swelling, joint and muscle pain, headache, and fluid retention. It can increase blood sugar and may unmask hypothyroidism. Carpal tunnel syndrome can occur in adults. Serious effects include intracranial hypertension, pancreatitis, slipped capital femoral epiphysis with hip pain and limping, progression of scoliosis, and increased risk of certain cancers or tumor growth. Seek urgent care for vision changes, severe abdominal pain, or breathing problems.

name: Pseudoephedrine
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Pseudoephedrine is a decongestant used to relieve nasal and sinus congestion due to colds, allergies, or sinusitis and to relieve ear congestion from air travel or ear infections. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth with or without food and with a full glass of water. Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time. Swallow extended release tablets whole. Measure liquids with a dosing device. Avoid taking near bedtime to reduce insomnia. Do not use more than directed on the label or by your clinician. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor within the past 14 days. Tell your clinician if you have high blood pressure, heart disease, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, glaucoma, enlarged prostate or urinary retention, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. Pseudoephedrine can raise blood pressure and heart rate and can cause nervousness and insomnia. Avoid combining with other decongestants or stimulants. Limit caffeine. Check with your clinician or pharmacist before using with other medicines. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific diet is required, but limit caffeinated beverages to reduce jitteriness and insomnia. Stay well hydrated. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you use it on a schedule, take it when you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take extra doses. If you use it only as needed, take it when symptoms require it. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include insomnia, nervousness, restlessness, dizziness, headache, nausea, and dry mouth. It can increase heart rate and blood pressure and may cause palpitations. Serious but rare effects include irregular heartbeat, hallucinations, seizures, severe allergic reactions, and urinary retention. Stop and seek care if you develop chest pain, severe headache, or neurologic symptoms.

name: Albuterol Oral Inhalation
instructions: Important warning: Overuse or increasing need for albuterol can signal worsening asthma and may be life threatening. Do not exceed the prescribed dose. This medicine is for quick relief of bronchospasm and prevention of exercise induced symptoms, not for daily long term control. Stop and seek medical care if breathing suddenly worsens after use, which may indicate paradoxical bronchospasm. Why is this medication prescribed? Albuterol is a short acting bronchodilator used to relieve wheezing and shortness of breath in asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and to prevent exercise induced bronchospasm. How should this medicine be used? Use exactly as directed. For metered dose inhalers, prime before first use or if not used for the period stated in the instructions, shake well, exhale fully, seal lips around the mouthpiece, inhale deeply while pressing down on the canister, then hold your breath as directed. If two puffs are prescribed, wait at least one minute between puffs. Use a spacer if recommended. For dry powder inhalers, follow the device specific steps. For nebulizer solution, use the prescribed dose in a nebulizer machine. Keep your rescue inhaler with you. Have your inhaler technique checked regularly. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, arrhythmias, seizures, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, or low potassium. Some medicines including nonselective beta blockers, diuretics that lower potassium, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, and tricyclic antidepressants can interact. Report chest pain, rapid or irregular heartbeat, severe tremor, or worsening breathing. If pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Limit excessive caffeine, which can worsen tremor and palpitations. Maintain adequate potassium intake if advised, especially if you use medicines that can lower potassium. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is used as needed for symptoms. If you use it to prevent exercise induced bronchospasm, take it as directed before exercise. If you miss that pre exercise dose, do not double later. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include tremor, nervousness, headache, throat irritation, cough, and fast heartbeat. It may cause palpitations, muscle cramps, and transient increases in blood sugar. Serious effects include paradoxical bronchospasm, chest pain, irregular heartbeat, low potassium, and allergic reactions.

name: Quinapril
instructions: Important warning: Do not use quinapril if you are pregnant. Drugs that act on the renin angiotensin system can cause injury and death to the developing fetus. Stop quinapril as soon as pregnancy is detected and contact your clinician right away. Why is this medication prescribed? Quinapril is an ACE inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure and to manage heart failure in combination with other medicines. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth once or twice daily with or without food at the same times each day. Your clinician will adjust the dose based on blood pressure and kidney function. Continue to take it even if you feel well. What special precautions should I follow? Do not take if you have a history of angioedema with ACE inhibitors or if you are allergic to quinapril. Tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, liver disease, dehydration, heart failure, diabetes, or if you use diuretics, potassium supplements, potassium sparing diuretics, or salt substitutes containing potassium. Avoid using with aliskiren if you have diabetes and avoid combining routinely with an angiotensin receptor blocker. This medicine can cause low blood pressure, high potassium, kidney problems, cough, and rare but serious angioedema that requires emergency care. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Limit salt substitutes and high potassium foods unless your clinician advises otherwise. Limit alcohol which can increase dizziness. Follow any sodium restriction plan recommended for your condition. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. If it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include cough, dizziness, headache, and fatigue. It can cause low blood pressure, increases in potassium and creatinine, and rash or taste changes. Serious effects include angioedema with swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat, severe abdominal pain which can be intestinal angioedema, jaundice, and rare low white blood cell counts.

name: Theophylline
instructions: Important warning: Theophylline has a narrow therapeutic range and high levels can cause serious and potentially life threatening side effects including seizures and dangerous heart rhythm problems. Blood levels may need monitoring and many drugs and illnesses can alter levels. Do not change dose or brand without medical guidance. Why is this medication prescribed? Theophylline is a bronchodilator used for maintenance treatment of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. It is not for sudden breathing attacks. How should this medicine be used? Take exactly as prescribed at the same times each day. Swallow extended release products whole and do not crush or chew. Do not switch between different products without checking with your clinician. Your dose may be adjusted based on symptoms and blood levels. Keep using your reliever inhaler for acute symptoms. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. Some antibiotics, antifungals, antidepressants, anti seizure medicines, stomach acid reducers, and others can raise or lower theophylline levels. Smoking tobacco or cannabis, changes in smoking status, fever, liver disease, heart failure, thyroid disease, and older age can change how your body handles theophylline. Avoid large amounts of caffeine because it can worsen side effects. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Maintain a consistent diet and limit excessive caffeine from coffee, tea, cola, energy drinks, or chocolate. Avoid alcohol excess. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember if it is not close to your next dose. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take extra doses. If you miss more than one dose or develop symptoms of toxicity such as persistent vomiting, severe restlessness, rapid or irregular heartbeat, or seizures, seek medical care. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include nausea, vomiting, stomach upset, headache, insomnia, tremor, nervousness, and palpitations. Serious effects include persistent vomiting, severe agitation, seizures, very fast or irregular heartbeat, low blood pressure, and confusion.

name: Hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and to reduce fluid buildup in conditions such as heart failure and certain kidney or liver disorders. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth once daily in the morning with or without food. Taking it earlier in the day can reduce nighttime urination. Your clinician may adjust the dose based on response and lab results. Continue taking even if you feel well. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, gout, diabetes, lupus, or an allergy to sulfonamide medicines. This medicine can cause low blood sodium, potassium, and magnesium, dehydration, low blood pressure, high uric acid, and increased blood sugar. It can rarely cause acute angle closure glaucoma or vision changes. It can increase sun sensitivity and has been associated with a higher risk of some non melanoma skin cancers with long term use, so use sun protection. Check with your clinician before using with lithium or digoxin. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Stay well hydrated. Your clinician may advise limiting sodium and eating potassium rich foods unless you take other medicines that raise potassium. Limit alcohol which can increase dizziness. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it when you remember unless it is late in the day and may cause nighttime urination. If it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include increased urination, dizziness, lightheadedness, and muscle cramps. It can cause electrolyte abnormalities such as low potassium or sodium, high uric acid with gout, and higher blood sugar. Less common effects include rash, photosensitivity, pancreatitis, and rare eye pain or sudden vision changes that need urgent care.

name: Acebutolol
instructions: Important warning: Do not stop acebutolol suddenly, especially if you have coronary artery disease. Abrupt discontinuation can worsen chest pain or cause heart attack. Your clinician will guide you to taper the dose over one to two weeks if it needs to be stopped. Why is this medication prescribed? Acebutolol is a beta blocker used to treat high blood pressure and certain abnormal heart rhythms and may be used to prevent angina. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth once or twice daily at the same times each day. Take consistently with respect to meals. Your clinician will adjust the dose based on blood pressure, heart rate, and clinical response. Do not stop taking it without medical advice. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes, thyroid disease, slow heart rate, heart block, heart failure, peripheral vascular disease, myasthenia gravis, depression, kidney or liver disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. This medicine can mask symptoms of low blood sugar and hyperthyroidism. Use caution with other medicines that slow the heart such as verapamil, diltiazem, and digoxin, and with clonidine. Report shortness of breath, wheezing, dizziness, fainting, very slow heart rate, swelling, or sudden weight gain. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific diet is required, but limit alcohol and be cautious with over the counter cold medicines that contain stimulants or decongestants. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is near the time of your next dose. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include tiredness, dizziness, nausea, and slow heart rate. It may cause low blood pressure, cold hands and feet, depression, sleep disturbances, and sexual dysfunction. Serious effects include wheezing or bronchospasm, fainting, heart block, worsening heart failure, and severe allergic reactions.

name: Aceclidine Ophthalmic
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Aceclidine eye drops are used to lower pressure inside the eye in people with open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension and to produce pupil constriction in certain situations. How should this medicine be used? Use exactly as directed by your eye doctor. Wash your hands, tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to make a small pocket, and place one drop in the affected eye or eyes. Do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. After instilling a drop, gently press the inner corner of the eye by the nose for one to two minutes and keep the eye closed to reduce systemic absorption. If you use other eye medicines, separate them by at least 5 to 10 minutes. Remove soft contact lenses before use and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting them. Use at the same times each day and do not stop without talking to your doctor. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have ever had a retinal detachment, severe nearsightedness, uveitis, asthma or other breathing problems, Parkinson disease, peptic ulcer disease, bowel or bladder obstruction, heart disease, or if you have had an allergic reaction to miotic eye drops such as pilocarpine. Aceclidine may cause blurred or dim vision especially in low light. Do not drive at night or perform tasks that require clear vision until you know how it affects you. Tell your doctor about all medicines you use including other glaucoma drops. If you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special diet is required. What should I do if I forget a dose? Use it as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not use two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include eye irritation, redness, tearing, brow ache, headache, and blurred vision. You may notice temporary nearsightedness. Less common but serious effects include retinal detachment with symptoms such as sudden flashes or floaters and a curtain over part of your vision, slow heartbeat, sweating, increased salivation, shortness of breath, or wheezing. Seek medical help right away if serious symptoms occur.

name: Perindopril
instructions: Important warning: Do not take perindopril if you are pregnant. Medicines that act on the renin angiotensin system can harm or cause death to an unborn baby. Stop perindopril as soon as you learn you are pregnant and contact your doctor right away. Why is this medication prescribed? Perindopril is an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure, to help manage heart failure, and to reduce the risk of heart events in some people with stable coronary artery disease. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth once daily at the same time each day with or without food. Your doctor may adjust the dose based on your blood pressure and kidney function. Take it regularly even if you feel well. Do not stop without talking to your doctor. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have ever had angioedema swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat, if you have kidney disease, liver disease, diabetes, dehydration, low sodium, renal artery stenosis, are on dialysis, or if you are Black because the risk of angioedema may be higher. Tell your doctor about all medicines you take including diuretics, potassium supplements, salt substitutes containing potassium, other drugs for blood pressure such as angiotensin receptor blockers or aliskiren, lithium, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, and any injectable gold therapy. Perindopril can cause dizziness especially when you first start it or when the dose is increased. Rise slowly from sitting or lying positions. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid potassium containing salt substitutes and limit high potassium supplements unless your doctor tells you otherwise. Limit alcohol which can increase dizziness. Stay well hydrated. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include cough, dizziness, headache, fatigue, and low blood pressure. It can increase potassium which may cause muscle weakness or abnormal heart rhythm. Serious side effects include angioedema with swelling of the face or throat and trouble breathing, kidney problems with reduced urine or swelling, and rare liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes. Seek urgent care for swelling of the face or throat or severe allergic reactions.

name: Acetaminophen Rectal
instructions: Important warning: Taking more than the recommended amount of acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage and can be life threatening. Adults should not take more than 4000 milligrams in 24 hours from all sources. Many prescription and nonprescription medicines contain acetaminophen sometimes labeled as APAP. Always read labels and ask if you are unsure. Avoid alcohol while using acetaminophen. Why is this medication prescribed? Rectal acetaminophen is used to relieve mild to moderate pain and to reduce fever when oral dosing is not preferred. How should this medicine be used? Use rectal suppositories exactly as directed. Wash your hands, remove the wrapper, if needed moisten the suppository with water, lie on your side, and gently insert the pointed end into the rectum. Remain lying for a few minutes to keep it in place. Dosing is based on age and weight and is usually every 4 to 6 hours as needed. Do not exceed the maximum daily dose. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have liver disease, drink three or more alcoholic drinks per day, are malnourished, have severe kidney disease, have rectal bleeding or proctitis, or take warfarin since regular acetaminophen use can increase bleeding risk. Tell your doctor about all medicines you use. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding ask your doctor about appropriate use and dosing. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid alcohol. Drink fluids as directed if you have fever. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you are taking it on a schedule, use it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. Do not use two doses at once. If you use it only as needed, use it when pain or fever occurs and follow the maximum daily limits. What side effects can this medication cause? Possible effects include rectal irritation, nausea, or rash. Serious reactions include severe skin reactions such as Stevens Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, or acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, and signs of liver injury such as nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, sweating, stomach pain, dark urine, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. Seek immediate help if overdose or serious reactions occur. Call poison control right away if too much is used.

name: Acetaminophen
instructions: Important warning: Taking more than the recommended amount of acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage and can be life threatening. Adults should not take more than 4000 milligrams in 24 hours from all sources. Many prescription and nonprescription medicines contain acetaminophen sometimes labeled as APAP. Always read labels and ask if you are unsure. Avoid alcohol while using acetaminophen. Why is this medication prescribed? Acetaminophen is used to relieve mild to moderate pain from conditions such as headache, muscle aches, arthritis, backache, toothache, colds, and to reduce fever. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth exactly as directed on the label or by your doctor. Use the dosing device that comes with liquid medicines. For children use weight based dosing. Space doses at least 4 to 6 hours apart and do not exceed the maximum number of doses per day. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have liver disease, drink three or more alcoholic drinks per day, are malnourished, or have severe kidney disease. Tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines you take including warfarin because regular acetaminophen use can increase bleeding risk. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding discuss appropriate use and dosing with your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid alcohol. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you are taking it on a schedule, take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you use it only as needed, take it when pain or fever occurs and follow the maximum daily limits. What side effects can this medication cause? Acetaminophen is usually well tolerated. Possible effects include nausea, stomach upset, or rash. Serious reactions include severe skin reactions such as Stevens Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, or acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, and signs of liver injury such as nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, sweating, stomach pain, dark urine, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. Seek medical help right away if serious reactions or overdose occur.

name: Acetaminophen and Codeine
instructions: Important warning: This medicine contains an opioid. Opioids can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. Serious and fatal breathing problems can occur, especially when starting the medicine or when the dose is increased. Children are at particular risk and this medicine must not be used in children younger than 12 years and must not be used after tonsil surgery or adenoid surgery in anyone younger than 18 years. Some people are ultrarapid metabolizers of codeine which can lead to dangerous levels of morphine. Do not take with alcohol, benzodiazepines, or other medicines that cause sleepiness unless directed by your doctor due to the risk of severe sedation, breathing problems, coma, and death. This product also contains acetaminophen. Taking more than 4000 milligrams of acetaminophen in 24 hours from all sources can cause severe liver damage. Why is this medication prescribed? The combination is used to relieve moderate pain when other pain relievers are not enough. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth exactly as directed, usually every 4 to 6 hours as needed at the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible time. Do not exceed the maximum daily dose of acetaminophen from all sources. Measure liquid carefully with the provided device. Store securely out of reach of others. Do not stop suddenly if you have taken it for more than a few days. Your doctor may tell you to lower the dose slowly. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have breathing problems such as asthma, COPD, or sleep apnea, head injury, seizures, liver or kidney disease, adrenal problems, low blood pressure, gallbladder disease, constipation, or pancreatitis. Tell your doctor about all medicines you take including sedatives, benzodiazepines, sleep medicines, muscle relaxants, other opioids, antidepressants or migraine medicines that affect serotonin, and CYP2D6 inhibitors or inducers. Do not drive or do activities that require alertness until you know how it affects you. Do not use during pregnancy unless your doctor decides the benefits outweigh risks. Use during pregnancy can cause neonatal withdrawal in the newborn. Do not breastfeed because life threatening sedation and breathing problems have occurred in infants exposed to codeine in breast milk. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Do not drink alcohol. Drink fluids, eat fiber, and consider a stool softener to help prevent constipation. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you take this on a schedule, take it as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you use it only as needed, take a dose when pain occurs and do not exceed prescribed limits. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, constipation, nausea, vomiting, and itching. Serious effects include slowed or stopped breathing, severe sleepiness, confusion, low blood pressure, fainting, serotonin syndrome with agitation, sweating, fast heartbeat, muscle stiffness, or diarrhea when combined with certain medicines, liver injury from too much acetaminophen, adrenal insufficiency with fatigue and weight loss, severe allergic reactions, and withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly after prolonged use. Seek urgent care for severe breathing problems, unusual sleepiness, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: Acetaminophen Injection
instructions: Important warning: Serious medication errors have occurred with acetaminophen injection including confusion between milligrams and milliliters and between pediatric and adult dosing. Acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage if too much is given. Your total daily dose from all sources must not exceed 4000 milligrams in adults. Tell your healthcare team about all acetaminophen containing medicines you have received. Why is this medication prescribed? Intravenous acetaminophen is used to relieve mild to moderate pain, to reduce fever, and with opioids to relieve moderate to severe pain when oral or rectal routes are not suitable. How should this medicine be used? It is given by a healthcare professional through a vein over about 15 minutes, with the dose based on your age and weight and your liver and kidney function. Doses are spaced at least 4 to 6 hours apart and the total daily dose must stay within recommended limits. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have liver disease, drink alcohol regularly, are malnourished, or have severe kidney disease. Tell your team about all medicines you receive including other acetaminophen products. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Do not drink alcohol. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is usually given in a hospital or clinic. If a dose is missed, your healthcare team will plan the next dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include nausea, vomiting, headache, and itching. You may have pain or redness at the infusion site. Serious reactions include allergic reactions such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing, severe skin reactions, low blood pressure, and liver injury especially with overdose. Tell your healthcare team right away if you develop concerning symptoms.

name: Acetaminophen, Butalbital, and Caffeine
instructions: Important warning: This product contains acetaminophen which can cause severe liver damage if you take more than 4000 milligrams in 24 hours from all sources or if you drink alcohol. It also contains butalbital, a barbiturate that can be habit forming, cause sedation, and lead to dependence and withdrawal if used regularly or in high amounts. Using it too often can cause medication overuse headache. Do not take with alcohol or other medicines that cause sleepiness unless directed by your doctor. Why is this medication prescribed? This combination is used to relieve tension headaches when simple pain relievers are not enough. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth exactly as directed, usually one tablet or capsule at the start of a headache and then as prescribed, often every 4 hours as needed. Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time. Do not exceed the maximum daily dose and limit how many days per month you use it to avoid rebound headaches. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have liver disease, a history of substance use disorder, mood disorders, porphyria, lung disease or sleep apnea, stomach ulcers, or kidney disease. Tell your doctor about all medicines you take including other sedatives, opioids, benzodiazepines, sleep aids, antidepressants, seizure medicines, and blood thinners. Avoid driving or tasks that require alertness until you know how it affects you. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, ask your doctor about risks and alternatives. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Do not drink alcohol. Limit other sources of caffeine such as coffee, tea, and energy drinks to avoid jitteriness and fast heartbeat. Drink water and maintain regular meals. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you take it on a regular schedule, take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you use it only as needed, take it at headache onset and follow your doctorâ€™s limits. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, nausea, stomach upset, and feeling restless or unable to sleep. It may cause constipation. Serious effects include severe liver injury from too much acetaminophen, severe allergic reactions, confusion, slow or shallow breathing, low blood pressure, dependence and withdrawal symptoms, and rash or severe skin reactions. Seek urgent care for breathing problems, severe drowsiness, or signs of liver injury such as dark urine or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: Acetazolamide
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to reduce pressure inside the eye in glaucoma, to prevent and lessen symptoms of acute mountain sickness, and as an add on treatment for certain types of seizures and for some cases of fluid retention. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth exactly as directed. Dosing depends on your condition. For mountain sickness prevention, start 24 to 48 hours before ascent and continue during ascent and for at least 48 hours at the altitude or until descent. For glaucoma and other conditions, take at evenly spaced times during the day. Swallow extended release capsules whole. Take with food or milk if stomach upset occurs and take earlier in the day to reduce nighttime urination. What special precautions should I follow? Do not take if you have had a severe reaction to sulfonamide medicines. Tell your doctor if you have severe liver disease, severe kidney disease, adrenal insufficiency, low sodium, low potassium, kidney stones, chronic lung disease, or metabolic acidosis. Tell your doctor about all medicines you take, especially high dose aspirin, lithium, topiramate, anticonvulsants, and other diuretics. It may cause dizziness or fatigue. Do not drive until you know how it affects you. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Drink plenty of fluids. Your doctor may advise you to limit foods or products that alkalinize the urine such as sodium bicarbonate and to consider potassium rich foods such as bananas and oranges to reduce the risk of low potassium. Avoid excessive alcohol at altitude. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it when you remember. If it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include frequent urination, tingling of the fingers or toes, taste changes, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, and dizziness. It can cause electrolyte imbalances and metabolic acidosis with symptoms such as drowsiness or rapid breathing. Less common but serious effects include kidney stones, severe skin rash, blood problems such as low white cells or platelets, liver problems, and severe allergic reactions. Seek medical help if severe rash, confusion, bruising, or breathing problems occur.

name: Medroxyprogesterone Injection
instructions: Important warning: Medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injection can cause significant loss of bone mineral density. Bone loss is greater with longer use and may not be completely reversible. Use beyond 2 years only if other methods of birth control are not adequate. Adequate calcium and vitamin D intake and weight bearing exercise are recommended. Why is this medication prescribed? The injection is used to prevent pregnancy. It may also be used for certain gynecologic conditions as determined by your doctor. How should this medicine be used? It is given as an intramuscular or subcutaneous injection by a healthcare professional once every 3 months about every 13 weeks. The first injection is usually given within the first 7 days of a menstrual period. If given outside this time you may need to use backup contraception for 7 days. Schedule your next injection before you leave the clinic. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you are pregnant. Tell your doctor if you have unexplained vaginal bleeding, breast cancer, a history of blood clots, stroke, or heart attack, osteoporosis or strong risk factors for bone loss, depression, diabetes, high blood pressure, migraine, liver disease, or if you smoke. This medicine does not protect against HIV or other sexually transmitted infections. It may cause a delay in return to fertility after stopping. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D intake and avoid smoking and excessive alcohol which worsen bone loss. Maintain a balanced diet and exercise regularly. What should I do if I forget a dose? If more than 13 weeks have passed since your last injection, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible. You may need a pregnancy test and to use backup contraception for at least 7 days after the next injection. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include changes in menstrual bleeding such as irregular bleeding or no periods, weight gain, headache, mood changes, decreased libido, acne, breast tenderness, and abdominal discomfort. It may reduce bone mineral density. Serious effects include blood clots with pain or swelling in a leg, chest pain or shortness of breath, stroke symptoms, severe depression, severe allergic reactions, and jaundice. Seek medical help right away for signs of blood clots or severe reactions.

name: Medroxyprogesterone
instructions: Important warning: In postmenopausal women, taking estrogen with progestin has been associated with an increased risk of heart attack, stroke, blood clots, breast cancer, and probable dementia. If medroxyprogesterone is prescribed with estrogen for hormone therapy, use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration needed. This medicine should not be used to prevent heart disease or dementia. Why is this medication prescribed? Oral medroxyprogesterone is used to treat secondary amenorrhea and abnormal uterine bleeding due to hormonal imbalance and to protect the lining of the uterus in postmenopausal women receiving estrogen therapy. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth exactly as directed, often once daily for a set number of days each month or in a cyclic schedule with estrogen. Take at the same time each day. Do not use if you are pregnant. If you have postmenopausal hormone therapy, your doctor will use the lowest dose for the shortest time that helps your symptoms. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have a history of blood clots, stroke, heart attack, liver disease, breast cancer or cancer of the reproductive organs, undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, severe headaches or migraine, fluid retention, depression, diabetes, or a history of jaundice during pregnancy. Tell your doctor about all medicines you take. Report new breast lumps, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe headache, vision changes, leg pain or swelling, or jaundice right away. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific diet is required, but if you are postmenopausal consider adequate calcium and vitamin D intake and avoid smoking to protect bone health. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you miss more than one dose in a cyclic regimen, contact your doctor for instructions. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include menstrual changes or spotting, breast tenderness, headache, nausea, bloating, mood changes, dizziness, and fatigue. Serious effects include blood clots, stroke, heart attack, vision or speech changes, severe headache, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe allergic reactions, and liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes. Seek medical help for serious symptoms.

name: Aspirin Rectal
instructions: Important warning: Aspirin can cause serious bleeding, especially in the stomach or brain, and should not be given to children or teenagers with viral illnesses such as flu or chickenpox due to the risk of Reyeâ€™s syndrome. Do not use if you have active bleeding, a bleeding disorder, recent stomach or intestinal ulcers, severe uncontrolled high blood pressure, or if you are allergic to aspirin or other NSAIDs. Why is this medication prescribed? Rectal aspirin is used to reduce fever, relieve mild to moderate pain, and decrease inflammation when oral dosing is not possible; in some cases a clinician may use it to reduce blood clot risk, but this requires specific dosing and medical supervision. How should this medicine be used? Use exactly as directed on the label or by your clinician. Wash your hands, remove the suppository wrapper, moisten the tip with water if needed, lie on your side, gently insert the suppository pointed end first into the rectum (adults generally about 2.5 cm or 1 inch), then remain lying for a few minutes to keep it from slipping out. Do not use more often or for longer than directed. Do not give to children or teens with a fever from viral illness. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about asthma, nasal polyps, stomach or intestinal ulcers or bleeding, GERD, kidney or liver disease, gout, anemia, low platelet count, G6PD deficiency, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and all medicines you use, especially blood thinners (warfarin, DOACs), other NSAIDs, SSRIs/SNRIs, corticosteroids, methotrexate, and alcohol. Stop and seek medical help for signs of bleeding (vomiting blood, black stools), allergic reaction, severe abdominal pain, or ringing in the ears with dizziness. Avoid using with other products that contain aspirin or salicylate. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Limit or avoid alcohol because it increases bleeding risk. Keep well hydrated; otherwise there are no specific dietary restrictions for the rectal form. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you use it on a schedule, insert it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. Do not use two doses at once. If you use it only as needed for pain or fever, take it when needed and do not exceed the maximum daily dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include local rectal irritation or burning, nausea, or upset stomach. Serious effects include stomach or intestinal bleeding, easy bruising or bleeding, ringing in the ears or hearing changes, dizziness, severe allergic reaction, and in children or teens with viral illness, Reyeâ€™s syndrome (persistent vomiting, confusion, behavior changes).

name: Aspirin
instructions: Important warning: Aspirin increases the risk of serious bleeding, including in the stomach and brain. Do not give aspirin to children or teenagers with viral illnesses such as flu or chickenpox due to the risk of Reyeâ€™s syndrome. Do not use if you have active bleeding, a bleeding disorder, a history of severe stomach ulcers or recent GI bleeding, or if you are allergic to aspirin or other NSAIDs. Why is this medication prescribed? Aspirin is used to treat pain, fever, and inflammation, and at low doses it is used to reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke in certain people as directed by a clinician. How should this medicine be used? Take exactly as directed. For pain or fever, use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time needed. For heart protection, take the low-dose aspirin at the same time each day. Swallow enteric-coated tablets whole; do not crush or chew them. Nonâ€“enteric-coated tablets for suspected heart attack should be chewed if instructed by emergency personnel. Take with a full glass of water and with food if it upsets your stomach. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have asthma or nasal polyps, stomach or intestinal ulcers, GERD, bleeding problems, kidney or liver disease, gout, anemia, low platelet count, G6PD deficiency, are pregnant (avoid especially in the last trimester) or breastfeeding, and list all medicines and supplements you take. Important interactions include blood thinners (warfarin, DOACs), other NSAIDs, SSRIs/SNRIs, corticosteroids, methotrexate, and alcohol. If you need occasional ibuprofen, take ibuprofen at least 8 hours before or at least 30 minutes after immediateâ€‘release aspirin used for heart protection. Stop and seek help for signs of bleeding, black stools, vomiting blood, unusual bruising, severe stomach pain, or allergic reactions. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Limit or avoid alcohol to reduce bleeding risk; there are no specific food restrictions, but taking with food may lessen stomach upset. Avoid other products containing aspirin or salicylates. What should I do if I forget a dose? For daily low-dose aspirin, take it as soon as you remember on the same day; if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. For as-needed use, take only when needed and do not exceed the labeled daily maximum. What side effects can this medication cause? Upset stomach, heartburn, nausea, and easy bruising can occur. Serious side effects include stomach or intestinal bleeding, severe allergic reactions, ringing in the ears or hearing changes, dizziness, kidney problems, and in children or teens with viral illness, Reyeâ€™s syndrome.

name: Tetracycline
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Tetracycline is an antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections such as acne, respiratory and skin infections, some sexually transmitted infections, cholera, and certain tick-borne diseases; it does not treat viral infections like colds or flu. How should this medicine be used? Take on an empty stomach with a full glass of water, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals and at least 2 hours before or 4 hours after dairy products, antacids, bismuth subsalicylate, or supplements containing calcium, magnesium, aluminum, iron, or zinc. Swallow capsules or tablets with plenty of water and remain upright for 30 minutes to reduce the risk of esophageal irritation. Take doses at evenly spaced intervals and complete the full course even if you feel better. Protect your skin from sun exposure. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding; tetracycline can harm an unborn baby and cause permanent tooth discoloration and bone effects and is generally avoided during pregnancy and in children under 8 years old. Inform your clinician about esophageal problems, liver or kidney disease, increased intracranial pressure, and all medicines you take. Do not take with isotretinoin or acitretin due to risk of increased intracranial pressure. Tetracycline may reduce the effectiveness of some hormonal contraceptives; use a reliable backup method during therapy. Seek medical care if you develop severe headache, vision changes, persistent diarrhea, severe abdominal pain, rash, or signs of allergy. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid milk and dairy products and mineral supplements around dosing times as they reduce absorption. Drink adequate fluids. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at the same time. What side effects can this medication cause? Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, photosensitivity with sunburn, and vaginal yeast infections can occur. Serious effects include esophagitis or ulcers, severe skin reactions, liver problems, permanent tooth discoloration in children, increased intracranial pressure with severe headache or vision changes, and Clostridioides difficileâ€“associated diarrhea.

name: Rabeprazole
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Rabeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), heal and prevent erosive esophagitis and duodenal ulcers, treat conditions with excessive stomach acid such as Zollingerâ€“Ellison syndrome, and in combination with antibiotics to eradicate Helicobacter pylori. How should this medicine be used? Take exactly as directed, usually once daily. Delayedâ€‘release tablets should be swallowed whole; do not crush or chew. Some formulations may be taken with or without food; follow your specific product instructions, and for sprinkle capsules give as directed before a meal. It is not for immediate relief of heartburn symptoms; allow several days for full effect. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have liver disease, osteoporosis, low magnesium, lupus, kidney problems, or if you have persistent diarrhea. Longâ€‘term use may increase the risk of fractures, vitamin B12 deficiency, low magnesium, kidney problems, and certain infections such as C. difficile diarrhea. Inform your clinician about all medicines you take, especially methotrexate, warfarin, digoxin, antifungals, antiretrovirals, and clopidogrel. Seek care for severe persistent diarrhea, rash with joint pain, signs of low magnesium such as muscle cramps or irregular heartbeat, or kidney issues. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid foods and beverages that worsen reflux such as large fatty meals, chocolate, caffeine, mint, alcohol, and acidic or spicy foods. Ensure adequate calcium and magnesium intake if on longâ€‘term therapy. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Headache, diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, gas, and rash may occur. Serious effects include severe watery diarrhea, low magnesium, kidney inflammation, new or worsening lupus, and allergic reactions.

name: Acitretin
instructions: Important warning: Acitretin can cause severe birth defects. Do not use if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding. People who can become pregnant must use two effective forms of contraception for at least 1 month before starting, during treatment, and for at least 3 years after the last dose; have regular pregnancy tests; and must not drink alcohol during treatment and for 2 months after stopping because alcohol can convert acitretin to etretinate, which stays in the body much longer and greatly extends the risk of birth defects. Do not donate blood during treatment and for 3 years after the last dose. Acitretin can cause liver injury and high triglycerides; periodic blood tests are required. Why is this medication prescribed? Acitretin is an oral retinoid used to treat severe psoriasis in adults when other treatments are not effective. How should this medicine be used? Take exactly as prescribed, usually once daily with your main meal to improve absorption. Swallow capsules whole. Do not take vitamin A supplements or other retinoids. Follow your clinicianâ€™s schedule for blood tests to monitor liver function and lipids. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about all medical conditions, especially liver disease, high cholesterol or triglycerides, diabetes, kidney disease, depression, bone disorders, and any eye problems, and list all medicines and supplements you use. Avoid tetracyclines and methotrexate due to serious interaction risks. Night vision may decrease; use caution when driving at night. Limit exposure to sunlight and UV therapy. Report severe headache, vision changes, mood changes, abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or signs of pancreatitis immediately. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Take with food, avoid all alcohol during treatment and for 2 months after stopping, avoid vitamin Aâ€“containing supplements and limit eating very highâ€“vitamin A foods in excess. If your triglycerides rise, follow clinicianâ€‘advised diet changes such as reducing sugars and saturated fats. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember the same day; if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at the same time. What side effects can this medication cause? Very common effects include dry lips and skin, dry eyes, nosebleeds, hair thinning, nail fragility, joint or muscle pain, headache, elevated liver enzymes, and increased cholesterol or triglycerides. Serious effects include liver injury, pancreatitis, severe skin reactions, depression or mood changes, vision changes including decreased night vision, and increased intracranial pressure.

name: Aclidinium Oral Inhalation
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Aclidinium is a longâ€‘acting anticholinergic bronchodilator used as a maintenance treatment to improve breathing in adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema; it is not for relief of sudden breathing problems. How should this medicine be used? Use the Pressair device exactly as prescribed, typically one inhalation twice daily about 12 hours apart. Prepare the device, exhale fully away from the device, seal your lips around the mouthpiece, inhale quickly and deeply until you hear a click, hold your breath for as long as comfortable, and then exhale slowly. Check the control window to confirm a successful dose. Do not use more than directed and do not use to treat acute bronchospasm; keep a rescue inhaler such as albuterol available for sudden symptoms. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have narrowâ€‘angle glaucoma, urinary retention, enlarged prostate or bladder neck obstruction, heart rhythm problems, or are pregnant or breastfeeding. Inform your clinician about all medicines you take, especially other anticholinergics. Stop use and seek care if you develop eye pain or vision changes, difficulty urinating, fast heartbeat, severe allergic reaction, or paradoxical bronchospasm. The device may contain lactose; tell your clinician if you have a severe milk protein allergy. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific dietary restrictions are required, but staying hydrated and avoiding smoking can help your lungs. What should I do if I forget a dose? Inhale a dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Dry mouth, cough, headache, sinus or throat irritation, and nausea can occur. Less common but serious effects include urinary retention, worsening narrowâ€‘angle glaucoma with eye pain or halos, fast or irregular heartbeat, and paradoxical bronchospasm.

name: Acoltremon Ophthalmic
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? I could not verify a medication named Acoltremon for ophthalmic use in standard references. It may be a misspelling, a regional brand, or an investigational product; please confirm the exact name or active ingredient with your prescriber or pharmacist. How should this medicine be used? Do not use until the medication name is confirmed; if you have the product, follow the specific instructions on its label and those provided by your eye care professional, including hand hygiene, proper drop technique, and dosing frequency. What special precautions should I follow? Verify the correct medication and concentration before use. Tell your clinician about eye conditions, contact lens use, allergies, and all medicines you use. Do not use any eye medication that looks discolored, contains particles, or is past its expiration date. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific dietary instructions apply to most ophthalmic drops. What should I do if I forget a dose? Once the medication is confirmed, follow the productâ€‘specific missed dose instructions; in general, apply a missed dose when remembered unless it is close to the next scheduled dose, and do not double the dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Side effects depend on the active ingredient; common eyeâ€‘drop effects include temporary burning or stinging, blurred vision, or eye irritation. Seek medical care for severe pain, vision changes, significant redness or swelling, or signs of allergic reaction. Please contact your clinician or pharmacist to confirm this medicationâ€™s identity before use.

name: Acoramidis
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Acoramidis is a transthyretin (TTR) stabilizer used to treat transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTRâ€‘CM) to help slow disease progression and improve outcomes. How should this medicine be used? Take exactly as prescribed, typically by mouth at a consistent time each day; your clinician will determine the dose. Swallow tablets or capsules whole unless your product instructions say otherwise. You may take it with or without food. Do not stop or change your dose without medical advice. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about liver or kidney problems, pregnancy or plans to become pregnant, and all medicines and supplements you use. Report new or worsening shortness of breath, swelling, weight gain, dizziness, or palpitations. Keep all scheduled followâ€‘up appointments and laboratory tests. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There are no specific food restrictions for acoramidis. If you have heart failure, follow clinicianâ€‘advised sodium and fluid restrictions and limit alcohol. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember on the same day; if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Side effects may include gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, nausea, or abdominal pain, swelling in the legs, fatigue, and dizziness. Serious allergic reactions are uncommon but require immediate medical attention. Your clinician may monitor liver tests and other labs during treatment.

name: Fluoride
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Fluoride helps prevent tooth decay by strengthening tooth enamel; it is available in toothpastes, mouth rinses, gels, varnishes applied by dental professionals, and as prescription drops or tablets in areas with low fluoride in the water supply. How should this medicine be used? Use fluoride products exactly as directed for your age and dental risk. Brush with a peaâ€‘sized amount of fluoride toothpaste twice daily (a smear for children under 3 years) and spit out excess; do not swallow. For prescription drops or tablets, use the dose based on your childâ€™s age and the fluoride level in your drinking water; drops can be placed directly in the mouth or in a small amount of nonâ€‘dairy liquid, preferably at bedtime after brushing. Mouth rinses and gels should be swished and spat out; do not swallow. What special precautions should I follow? Keep all fluoride products out of reach of children to prevent accidental swallowing. Supervise young children during brushing. Tell your clinician or dentist if you have kidney disease or are on a lowâ€‘salt or special diet. Combining multiple fluoride sources may increase the risk of fluorosis in children; your dentist can help assess total exposure. Avoid taking fluoride tablets at the same time as calcium, magnesium, or aluminumâ€‘containing products as they reduce absorption. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Know your waterâ€™s fluoride content to avoid excess; your dentist or local water authority can provide this. Avoid giving fluoride tablets with milk or calciumâ€‘containing foods; separate by at least 2 hours. What should I do if I forget a dose? For supplements, give the missed dose when remembered unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. Do not double doses. Resume regular brushing or rinsing at the next scheduled time. What side effects can this medication cause? When used as directed, side effects are uncommon. Possible effects include temporary tooth staining with some stannous fluoride products, mild mouth irritation, or stomach upset if swallowed. Chronic excessive intake during tooth development can cause dental fluorosis (mottling of enamel). Large accidental ingestions can cause nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and electrolyte disturbances; seek emergency care if a large amount is swallowed.

name: Tocilizumab Injection
instructions: Important warning: Tocilizumab can increase the risk of serious, sometimes fatal infections including tuberculosis, bacterial, invasive fungal, and opportunistic infections. Your clinician will evaluate and treat latent TB if needed before starting and monitor closely during treatment; do not start if you have an active infection. Tocilizumab can also cause gastrointestinal perforation, especially in people with diverticulitis, and can cause severe decreases in white blood cells or platelets and elevations in liver enzymes; regular blood tests are required. Why is this medication prescribed? Tocilizumab is an interleukinâ€‘6 receptor inhibitor used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, giant cell arteritis, polyarticular and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, cytokine release syndrome after certain CARâ€‘T therapies, and in some settings hospitalized adults with severe COVIDâ€‘19 in combination with steroids. How should this medicine be used? Tocilizumab is given by subcutaneous injection at home on a schedule set by your clinician (for example every week or every other week) or by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital for certain indications. For injections, allow the prefilled syringe or autoinjector to reach room temperature, inspect the solution, choose a new site each time (abdomen, thigh, or upper arm), and inject as instructed; do not shake. Keep all lab and followâ€‘up appointments. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about all infections or exposures, TB or hepatitis history, GI disease such as diverticulitis, liver disease, low blood counts, recent vaccinations, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and all medicines you take. Do not receive live vaccines during treatment. Tocilizumab can alter the levels of other drugs metabolized by the liver; your clinician may need to adjust doses of drugs such as warfarin, statins, cyclosporine, and some oral contraceptives. Seek medical care promptly for fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, painful urination, severe stomach pain, black stools, easy bruising or bleeding, yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe headache, or allergic reactions. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There are no specific food restrictions, but limit alcohol to reduce liver risk and maintain a balanced diet to support immune health and lipid control. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a subcutaneous dose, take it as soon as you remember if it is within a few days of the scheduled time; otherwise skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. Do not take two doses at once. For infusions, contact your clinic to reschedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Injection site reactions, upper respiratory infections, headache, dizziness, increased blood pressure, and elevated cholesterol can occur. Serious effects include severe infections, GI perforation, low white blood cells or platelets, liver injury, allergic reactions, and reactivation of tuberculosis.

name: Cosyntropin Injection
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Cosyntropin is used to test how well your adrenal glands respond to adrenocorticotropic hormone as part of an ACTH stimulation test to help diagnose adrenal insufficiency and related conditions. How should this medicine be used? It is given by a healthcare professional as a single intravenous or intramuscular injection. Blood samples for cortisol are taken before the dose and at specific times after the dose, most often at 30 and 60 minutes, following your laboratory protocol. Follow any pre test instructions such as timing of other medicines. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor about all medicines and supplements, especially steroids, oral estrogens, mifepristone, ketoconazole, and anti seizure medicines, since they can affect test results. Tell your doctor about allergies and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. Recent or ongoing steroid use can blunt the response and may require rescheduling. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special diet is needed. Follow any fasting or timing instructions given by your testing center. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss your scheduled test or injection appointment, contact your healthcare provider to reschedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Temporary flushing, nausea, headache, dizziness, increased blood pressure, and pain or irritation at the injection site may occur. Rarely, allergic reactions with rash, wheezing, or swelling can occur. Seek urgent care for severe reactions.

name: Corticotropin, Repository Injection
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Corticotropin repository is used to treat infantile spasms and to manage short term flares of certain inflammatory or autoimmune conditions such as multiple sclerosis exacerbations and nephrotic syndrome when corticosteroid effects are needed. How should this medicine be used? It is given by subcutaneous or intramuscular injection. Dosing depends on the condition being treated and your response. Your clinician will teach you or a caregiver how to inject it and how to taper the dose. Do not stop suddenly after longer courses unless your doctor tells you to because this can cause adrenal insufficiency. What special precautions should I follow? This medicine can suppress your immune system and your adrenal glands. Tell your doctor if you have an active infection, a history of stomach ulcers, osteoporosis, diabetes, high blood pressure, heart failure, kidney problems, glaucoma, cataracts, mood disorders, seizures, or thyroid disease. Avoid live vaccines during treatment and for a period after. Tell your doctor about all medicines, including diuretics, potassium lowering drugs, anticoagulants, aspirin and other NSAIDs, diabetes medicines, and vaccines. If you develop fever, severe stomach pain, black stools, severe mood changes, or vision problems, contact your doctor. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Your doctor may advise limiting salt, ensuring adequate potassium, calcium, and vitamin D, and moderating carbohydrate intake if you have diabetes. Avoid alcohol to reduce the risk of stomach bleeding. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose, then skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you miss more than one dose, call your doctor to adjust the taper schedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Swelling, weight gain, increased appetite, mood changes, insomnia, elevated blood pressure, high blood sugar, acne, easy bruising, muscle weakness, delayed wound healing, and increased risk of infections. Serious effects include stomach bleeding, severe headache or vision changes, severe allergic reactions, and seizures.

name: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) Vaccine
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? The Hib vaccine helps prevent serious infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b such as meningitis, pneumonia, epiglottitis, and bloodstream infections, mainly in young children and in certain high risk adults. How should this medicine be used? It is given as an intramuscular injection by a healthcare provider. The routine series is usually at 2 and 4 months with a booster at 12 to 15 months, and some products include a 6 month dose. Unvaccinated older children and certain adults with asplenia, sickle cell disease, or after stem cell transplant may receive catch up doses per guidelines. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your provider about any severe allergy to a previous Hib vaccine or to vaccine components and if the child has a bleeding disorder or takes blood thinners. Vaccination may be deferred for moderate or severe illness. People with weakened immune systems can receive the vaccine but may have a reduced response. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special dietary instructions are needed. What should I do if I forget a dose? If a dose is missed, schedule the next visit as soon as possible. The series does not need to be restarted, and the remaining doses will be given on a catch up schedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Redness, swelling, or soreness at the injection site, mild fever, irritability, sleepiness, and decreased appetite can occur. Severe allergic reactions are rare but require urgent care and present with hives, wheezing, or facial swelling.

name: Doxycycline
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Doxycycline treats many bacterial infections including acne, skin and respiratory infections, some sexually transmitted infections, Lyme disease and other tick borne illnesses, and it is used to prevent malaria in travelers. It is also used for rosacea. How should this medicine be used? Take it by mouth with a full glass of water and remain upright for at least 30 minutes. Take it at the same times each day and for the full course even if you feel better. For malaria prevention start 1 to 2 days before travel, continue daily while in the area, and continue for 4 weeks after leaving. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you are allergic to tetracyclines, if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding. It is usually avoided in children younger than 8 years except for serious infections. It can increase sun sensitivity so use sun protection. Do not take it within 2 hours of antacids, calcium or iron supplements, magnesium, zinc, or bismuth subsalicylate. It may reduce the effectiveness of some oral contraceptives, so use an additional birth control method. Tell your doctor if you have liver disease or trouble swallowing. What special dietary instructions should I follow? You may take it with food if your stomach is upset, but avoid taking it with dairy products or calcium fortified foods at the same time. Drink plenty of water. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, sun sensitivity with rash or sunburn, headache, yeast infections, and irritation or ulcers in the esophagus. Serious effects include severe allergic reactions and increased pressure in the skull with severe headache and vision changes.

name: Chlorpheniramine
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy and common cold symptoms including sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and hives. How should this medicine be used? Take it by mouth as directed by your doctor or the product label. It comes as immediate release and extended release tablets, capsules, liquids, and chewable forms. Measure liquid doses carefully and do not exceed the recommended dose. Avoid taking other products that also contain antihistamines. What special precautions should I follow? This medicine may cause drowsiness and impair your ability to drive or operate machinery. Avoid alcohol and other sedating medicines. Tell your doctor if you have glaucoma, enlarged prostate, difficulty urinating, asthma or chronic bronchitis, stomach ulcers, thyroid disease, heart disease, high blood pressure, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. Children and older adults may be more sensitive to side effects. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special diet is required. Avoid alcohol. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it when you remember. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not double the dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Drowsiness, dizziness, dry mouth, dry eyes, blurred vision, constipation, difficulty urinating, fast heartbeat, confusion especially in older adults, and rarely allergic reactions.

name: Ursodiol
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Ursodiol is used to dissolve certain cholesterol gallstones in people who cannot have surgery and to treat primary biliary cholangitis by improving bile flow and reducing liver inflammation. How should this medicine be used? Take it by mouth with food in divided doses as prescribed. Swallow tablets or capsules whole. If using a liquid, shake well and measure with a dosing device. It may take several months to see the full effect and your doctor will monitor liver tests and imaging. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor about allergies, pregnancy, and breastfeeding. Tell your doctor if you have gallbladder or bile duct obstruction, pancreatitis, frequent biliary colic, or liver failure. Tell your doctor about all medicines, especially bile acid binding resins such as cholestyramine or colestipol, aluminum antacids, oral estrogens, and some birth control pills that can reduce effectiveness. Take other medicines that bind bile acids at a different time as advised. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Take doses with meals. Follow your doctorâ€™s advice about a balanced diet and maintaining a healthy weight. If you have gallstones, your doctor may advise limiting very high cholesterol foods. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Diarrhea or constipation, stomach pain, nausea, headache, dizziness, back pain, cough, skin rash, and occasionally worsening of liver tests. Contact your doctor if you notice jaundice, dark urine, or severe abdominal pain.

name: Interferon Gamma-1b Injection
instructions: Why is this medication prescribed? Interferon gamma 1b helps reduce the frequency and severity of infections in chronic granulomatous disease and improves outcomes in severe malignant osteopetrosis by enhancing immune function. How should this medicine be used? It is given as a subcutaneous injection, usually three times per week in the evening. A healthcare provider will teach you how to prepare and inject it, rotate injection sites, and store the vials. Do not shake the vial and do not use if the solution is cloudy or contains particles. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor if you have a history of depression, seizures, heart disease, liver or kidney disease, thyroid problems, bone marrow suppression, or autoimmune disease. This medicine can cause flu like symptoms and can affect liver enzymes and blood counts, so regular monitoring is needed. Tell your doctor about all medicines and supplements, including other immune therapies and theophylline. If you become pregnant or are breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. Seek care for severe mood changes, persistent fever, severe abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or signs of infection. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special diet is required. Stay well hydrated and consider a light snack with the dose if advised to help with flu like symptoms. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember if it is the same day. If it is the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Fever, chills, fatigue, muscle aches, headache, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, redness or pain at the injection site, elevated liver enzymes, low white blood cell count, mood changes, and rarely serious allergic reactions.

name: Dactinomycin
instructions: Important warning: Dactinomycin can cause severe bone marrow suppression that increases the risk of serious infection and bleeding, serious and sometimes fatal liver injury including blockage of liver blood vessels, and severe tissue damage if the drug leaks outside the vein. It must be given under the supervision of experienced healthcare professionals with the ability to manage severe complications. Why is this medication prescribed? Dactinomycin is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat certain cancers including Wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma, testicular cancer, and gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. How should this medicine be used? It is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital, often in cycles and sometimes with other chemotherapy medicines. Doses are based on body size or weight. Your team will monitor blood counts and organ function before each dose and take precautions to prevent leakage outside the vein. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor about any infections, fevers, unusual bruising or bleeding, liver disease, prior radiation to the liver, and all medicines and supplements. Avoid live vaccines during treatment and until your doctor says it is safe. Use effective contraception during treatment and for the advised period after the last dose and do not breastfeed. Report mouth sores, severe nausea or vomiting, yellowing of the skin or eyes, abdominal pain, or swelling at the infusion site. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There is no specific diet required. Eat small frequent meals and drink fluids to help with nausea and maintain hydration. Avoid alcohol to reduce liver strain. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is given by your oncology team. If you miss an appointment, contact them to reschedule as soon as possible. What side effects can this medication cause? Nausea, vomiting, mouth sores, diarrhea, loss of appetite, hair loss, fatigue, rash, elevated liver enzymes, severe bone marrow suppression that can lead to infections, anemia, or bleeding, severe tissue injury if the drug leaks outside the vein, and serious liver injury that can be life threatening.

name: Alteplase Injection
instructions: Important warning: Alteplase can cause severe and life threatening bleeding including bleeding in the brain. It should be used only by trained clinicians who can select appropriate patients and monitor and treat bleeding complications. Why is this medication prescribed? Alteplase is a thrombolytic medicine used to dissolve blood clots in acute ischemic stroke within a specific time window, in some cases of heart attack when other treatments are not available, in massive pulmonary embolism with instability, and to clear blocked central venous catheters. How should this medicine be used? It is given by intravenous infusion in a hospital with continuous monitoring, with dose and duration based on your weight and the condition being treated. For catheter clearance, it is instilled into the catheter and withdrawn after a set time. Blood pressure and neurological status are closely monitored and brain imaging is used to confirm stroke eligibility. What special precautions should I follow? You should not receive alteplase if you have active internal bleeding, certain types of prior brain bleeding, very high uncontrolled blood pressure, recent major surgery or head trauma, or specific bleeding disorders. Tell your team about recent procedures, strokes, gastrointestinal bleeding, ulcers, liver disease, use of blood thinners, and if you are pregnant or postpartum. Invasive procedures and intramuscular injections are minimized for 24 hours after treatment when possible. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No dietary instructions apply during emergency treatment. After treatment, follow your care teamâ€™s advice which may include limiting alcohol and following a heart healthy diet. What should I do if I forget a dose? Not applicable in emergencies. If you miss an appointment for catheter clearance, contact your clinic to reschedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Bleeding from gums or nose, bruising, low blood pressure, nausea, fever, and serious bleeding including intracranial hemorrhage with sudden severe headache, weakness, confusion, or loss of consciousness, and allergic reactions including swelling of the face or tongue especially when used with certain blood pressure medicines.

name: Estrogen and Progestin (Hormone Replacement Therapy)
instructions: Important warning: Estrogen with or without progestin increases the risk of blood clots, stroke, heart attack, breast cancer, and dementia in some women.
